data.title: Calumet Specialty Prods Cut to Sell From Neutral by UBS
data.description: (10:46 GMT) Calumet Specialty Prods Price Target Cut to $15.00/Share From $20.50 by UBS

data.title: SocGen's Overnight Economic News Summary
data.description:
Societe Generale in its early Tuesday economic news summary pointed out:

— United States pauses tariffs on Mexico and Canada for one month, Canadian Prime Minister Trudeau rows back on retaliation, deploys border personnel. reverses 2.9% spike, returns below 1.4450. retraces below 50dma (20.42). 10-year U.S. Treasury up to 4.57% from 4.46% low.

— China retaliates with a 10% tariff from next Monday on U.S. cars, farm equipment, energy shipments. Imposes export control on tungsten-related materials, probes Google over anti-trust law breaches. USD/CNH offered below 7.30.

— Federal Reserve's Bostic (non-voter): not clear what President Trump's actions add up to for the U.S. economy. Collins (voter): there's no urgency for making additional adjustments. Goolsbee (voter): Trump policies led to uncertainties that could slow rate cuts.

— Day ahead: U.S. JOLTS job openings. Fed speaker Bostic and Daly. European Central Bank's Villeroy. United Kingdom benchmark auction.

— Nikkei +0.7%, EUR 10-year IRS +2bps at 2.37%, Brent crude -0.8% at $75.4/barrel, Gold -0.3% at $2,809/oz.

data.title: Currencies steady as trade war concerns persist
data.description:
Key points:
  • Stronger US dollar adds pressure
  • Czech National Bank expected to resume policy easing
  • Poland expected to keep rates unchanged

Most central European currencies steadied on Tuesday after a sell-off the previous session, although concerns over a possible trade war between the U.S. and its trading partners limited gains.

Prague's stock index (.PX) was up 0.8% while Warsaw rose 0.5%. Both indices fell the fastest since late last year on Monday as markets digested the announcement of U.S. tariffs on imports from Canada, Mexico and China.

The Hungarian forint added 0.1% on Tuesday and was trading at 407.9 to the euro.

"The trade war caused only smaller swings in the forint's rate. There is a strong support level at 406 and a significant resistance at 408.5," brokerage Equilor wrote in a client note.

On Monday, U.S. President Donald Trump agreed to a 30-day pause in 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada, giving some relief to markets.

China, however, had no such reprieve, and on Tuesday announced tariffs on some U.S. imports in retaliation.

The Polish zloty was up 0.09% and traded at 4.225 per euro, while the Czech crown edged up 0.06% to trade at 25.19 to the euro.

Analysts said CEE assets face further pressure as the impact of tariffs so far already affects European economies, which Trump has said he also plans to target directly with trade measures.

"We see the CZK and HUF being exposed to this environment and a stronger US dollar will keep this part of the region under pressure," ING wrote in a note.

"The CNB rate cut on Thursday and higher inflation in Hungary next week are FX negative on the local side in our view."

The Czech National Bank is scheduled to meet on Thursday and is expected resume its policy-easing cycle and cut rates by 0.25% basis points to 3.75%.

The monetary policy council of the National Bank of Poland has a meeting on Wednesday where rates are widely expected to remain unchanged.

data.title: Palantir Technologies Is Maintained at Buy by B of A Securities
data.description: (10:50 GMT) Palantir Technologies Price Target Raised to $125.00/Share From $90.00 by B of A Securities

data.title: Morgan Stanley Adjusts Price Target on Nasdaq to $96 From $93, Keeps Overweight Rating
data.description: Nasdaq has an average rating of overweight and mean price target of $90.35, according to analysts polled by FactSet.

data.title: Prospex Energy's El Romeral Gas Drilling Plan Enters Spanish Ministry Review Process
data.description:
Prospex Energy said Tuesday the Spanish regulatory authority started the statutory consultation on the environmental impact assessment for its plan to drill five new natural gas wells at the El Romeral concessions.

Spain's Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge will review the assessment, with a final decision expected to take 90 to 180 days from Junta de Andalucía's recommendations.

The European gas and power projects-focused company holds a 49.9% interest in the El Romeral project through its Spanish affiliate Tarba Energía. The well drilling project aims to extract biogenic gas from shallow subsurface horizons.

data.title: China Retaliates With Tariffs on US Goods, Google Antitrust Probe Amid Trade Tensions
data.description:
China has Tuesday imposed retaliatory measures, including new tariffs on United States imports including coal, LNG, crude oil, and farm equipment after fresh US tariffs on Chinese goods took effect, multiple media outlets reported Tuesday.

The new Chinese tariffs, set at 15% for coal and LNG, and 10% for crude oil, farm machinery, and certain vehicles, will take effect on Feb. 10.

In addition, China's State Administration for Market Regulation launched an antitrust investigation into Google over suspected violation of the country's anti-monopoly law, multiple media reports said Tuesday.

Additionally, China's Commerce Ministry has reportedly placed PVH , owner of brands such as Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger, and Illumina on its "unreliable entity" list, the reports said.

China's Commerce Ministry and its Customs Administration also imposed export controls on critical metals used in electronics and military equipment, media reports said.

Google, PVH, and Illumina did not immediately respond to requests for comment from MT Newswires.

data.title: Evercore ISI Adjusts Price Target on Wells Fargo & Co. to $91 From $88, Maintains Outperform Rating
data.description: Wells Fargo & Co. has an average rating of overweight and mean price target of $84.33, according to analysts polled by FactSet.

data.title: Rohm's Nine-Month Profit Slumps to 210 Million Yen
data.description:
Rohm's recorded a profit attributable to owners of 210 million yen for the nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024, compared to 45.1 billion yen in the year-ago period.

The company's earnings per share dropped to 0.27 yen from 112.08 yen a year ago, according to a Monday filing with the Tokyo Exchange.

Net sales of the electronics company came in at 344.6 billion yen, 3% lower than 355.1 billion yen a year earlier.

Rohm expects an attributable loss of 6 billion yen, a loss per share of 15.55 yen, net sales of 450 billion yen, and a final dividend of 25 yen per share for the fiscal year ending March. 31.

data.title: Premier Energies Declares Interim Dividend
data.description:
Premier Energies' board has declared an interim dividend of 0.50 Indian rupees per share, according to a Monday filing with the Indian exchanges.

The dividend is payable to the shareholders of record on Feb. 14.

data.title: Kohl's Is Maintained at Hold by Jefferies
data.description: (10:43 GMT) Kohl's Price Target Cut to $12.00/Share From $15.00 by Jefferies

data.title: Ajinomoto's Profit Gains More Than 6% in Fiscal Nine Months
data.description:
Ajinomoto's profit attributable to owners of the parent rose 6.2% to 82.4 billion yen for the nine months ended Dec. 31, 2024 (IFRS), from 77.60 billion yen a year ago mainly boosted by higher sales in the seasonings and foods segment.

The company said basic earnings per share (EPS) increased to 163.08 yen from 148.61 yen a year ago, according to a Tokyo Stock Exchange filing on Monday.

Sales grew 7.8% to 1.151 trillion yen from 1.067 trillion yen a year earlier.

It forecasted attributable profit to increase 9.0% to 95 billion yen or 188.72 yen per share, with sales expected to rise 6.5% to 1.533 trillion yen for the fiscal year ending March 31.

The company expects to pay a year-end dividend of 40.00 yen per share for the current fiscal year.

Ajinomoto shares gained 4% at market close.

data.title: Most US Treasury Yields Advance Early Tuesday With 10-Year Jumping 3.6 Basis Points to 4.58%
Singamas Container to See Higher Profit in 2024
data.description:
Singamas Container expects an attributable profit of at least $30 million for 2024, up from around $19.4 million a year prior, a Tuesday bourse filing said.

The container manufacturer attributed the forecast mainly to a rise in the demand for dry freight containers, increased export volume, and a higher gross profit margin.

data.title: Indian Shares End Higher, Sentiment Boosted After Tariff Delays — Market Talk
data.description: Indian shares closed higher, tracking gains seen across most regional markets. Investor sentiment saw a boost after Trump paused the proposed tariffs on Mexico and Canada. China retaliated with new tariffs on the U.S., but analysts say Beijing's initial move was weaker than expected, signaling lower risks than anticipated. Lenders and tech companies led the gains. IndusInd Bank rose 3.5% and Axis Bank was 2.6% higher. HCL Technologies put up 2.5% and Infosys gained 1.9%. ITC Hotels was the biggest loser on the benchmark index, dropping 4.2%. The benchmark Sensex Index ended 1.8% higher at 78583.81. (sherry.qin@wsj.com)

data.title: Global Forex and Fixed Income Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering FX and Fixed Income. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

1044 GMT - The Canadian dollar remain vulnerable even after President Trump agreed to pause 25% tariffs on Canada, Monex Europe analysts say in a note. Any celebrations look somewhat premature, they say. "The Canadian government will likely have to make much more onerous concessions to ensure that the tariff threat is lifted permanently, and this appears far from a done deal to us." This recent drama could resume in a few weeks with risks that next time won't result in another deal for U.S. tariffs to be suspended, they say. USD/CAD trades flat at 1.4434 after hitting a 22-year high of 1.4793 Monday, according to FactSet. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

1029 GMT - The Bank of England is widely expected to cut interest rates when it announces a decision Thursday, and it could hint at another interest-rate cut in March, Berenberg's senior economist Andrew Wishart says in a note. "Until now, the BOE has cut at alternate meetings, but a stagnating economy and declining employment argue for more urgent action," he says. Markets price in a total of 30 basis points of interest-rate cuts in February and March, LSEG Refinitiv data show. "It is sensible for the BOE to lower interest rates to prevent a larger drop in [U.K.] employment," Wishart says. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

1027 GMT - China's tariff retaliation is smaller than expected and largely symbolic, Morningstar analyst Kai Wang says in a note. Trump's latest 10% blanket tariff on Chinese goods has an immediate impact only on some industries, such as home appliances, lithium batteries and EVs, the analyst says. Wang notes that the products included in China's countermeasures, such as coal and liquefied natural gas, accounted for just 12% of the country's imports from the U.S., implying less risk than previously expected. However, the analyst still warns of the possibility of an escalating trade war given Trump's unpredictability.(sherry.qin@wsj.com)

1008 GMT - Donald Trump's trade policy announcements over the weekend raise the question of whether there is a bigger risk from tariffs to the eurozone than previously thought, according to Capital Economics' Andrew Kenningham. A 10% universal tariff imposed by the U.S. might shave 0.1% to 0.2% off eurozone GDP, he says in a note. But a 25% tariff, as imposed but suspended on Canada and Mexico, would have a more-than-proportionately larger effect because it would be harder for companies and exchange-rate moves to cushion the blow, Kenningham warns. A ball-park estimate is that would cut eurozone GDP by around 0.5%, leaving growth close to zero this year. Additionally, a prohibitive tariff of, say, 100% on European vehicles could on its own push Germany into recession. (edward.frankl@wsj.com)

1005 GMT - The dollar could suffer a further pullback if the U.S. and China move towards a de-escalation in their trade dispute, ING analyst Francesco Pesole says in a note. A new 10% U.S. tariff on China took effect Tuesday and China has announced retaliatory tariffs. Markets seem to price in a good chance of the U.S. and China striking a deal and delaying tariffs after Trump agreed to pause planned 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico. However, the case for significant dollar depreciation is weak as the tariff threat remains, Pesole says. Trump has "more concretely introduced the tariff threat into daily market news." The DXY dollar index falls 0.5% to 108.484. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0957 GMT - U.S. tariffs are likely to end up not as bad as markets had feared, says Jefferies' Mohit Kumar in a note. Jefferies is therefore positive on risky assets over a 3-month to 6-month horizon. The macroeconomic backdrop remains supportive and positioning is light, the global economist says. That said, the coming days are likely to be dominated by headlines around negotiations with China, while Europe is likely the next in the tariffs and negotiations story, he says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0948 GMT - Sterling falls on the day but remains comfortably above Monday's lows against the dollar when U.S. President Trump's tariffs on Canada and Mexico--which he later agreed to pause--unsettled markets. ING analyst Francesco Pesole says any sterling losses should be limited because tariffs shouldn't unduly harm the U.K. economy. Exports to the U.S. are less than 2% of gross domestic product, while Trump "seems in no rush to hit the U.K. with tariffs," he says in a note. U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer's trip to Brussels to discuss security and defence is positive for sterling as it signals intent to repair EU relations, he says. Sterling falls 0.3% to $1.2409, still well above Monday's low of $1.2248. EUR/GBP rises 0.1% to 0.8322. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0919 GMT - The U.K. March 2030 gilt, which is due to be auctioned on Tuesday, trades at a historically cheap level and this should attract some demand at Tuesday's auction from investors seeking relative value, RBC Capital Markets analysts say in a note. However, this bond is less appealing as the Debt Management Office is set to sell this bond once more this quarter on March 5. "We're struggling to get particularly excited about the bond on relative value here given its heavy tapping schedule ahead," the analysts say. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

0908 GMT - The yields on U.K. government bonds, or gilts, rise, tracking moves in their U.S. and eurozone counterparts after U.S. President Trump paused tariffs on Canada and Mexico for a month, sparking a shift away from safe-haven bonds for now. Tariffs remain a risk and investors are concerned about the harm this could do to the U.K. economy, dampening growth while lifting inflation, Pantheon Macroeconomics economists say in a note. "We think President Trump's tariffs, by fracturing supply chains, will be stagflationary for the U.K." Tariffs could potentially mean fewer interest-rate cuts by the Bank of England as inflation rebounds, the economists say. The 10-year gilt yield climbs 4 basis points to last trade at 4.520%, Tradeweb data show. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

0855 GMT - The dollar falls after President Trump delayed tariffs on Canada and Mexico for one month, but uncertainty remains and this could soon lift the safe-haven dollar once more, Commerzbank's Antje Praefcke says in a note. There is a risk of new tariff announcements coming at any time, she says. "The next shock is bound to come, and this will probably be dollar-positive again." Key U.S. economic data this week--including ISM data on services Wednesday and monthly jobs data Friday--will also likely lift the dollar as long as they underpin the story of a resilient U.S. economy, she says. The DXY dollar index falls 0.4% to 108.589, having hit a three-week high of 109.881 Monday. (jessica.fleetham@wsj.com)

0843 GMT - The euro remains under pressure as tariff risks remain heightened even after President Trump agreed to pause tariffs on Canada and Mexico, Danske Bank analyst Stefan Mellin says in a note. Tariff headlines will likely remain the primary driver of price action in the coming weeks, with a risk of Trump announcing measures against Europe, he says. Still, Trump looks to be using tariff announcements "primarily as a negotiating tool" and this could help the euro to recover back into a $1.04-$1.05 range. "We believe Trump is ultimately likely to under-deliver on maintaining tariffs for an extended period," Mellin says. The euro falls 0.2% on the day to $1.0323. It hit a three-week low of $1.0213 Monday, according to FactSet. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)The dollar falls slightly after President Trump agreed to hold off imposing 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico. "Dollar Edges Lower After Trump Pauses Canada, Mexico Tariffs — Market Talk," at 0756 GMT, incorrectly said Trump agreed to hold off imposing 25% tariffs on China.

data.title: Canadian Dollar Remains Vulnerable to Tariff Threat — Market Talk
data.description: The Canadian dollar remain vulnerable even after President Trump agreed to pause 25% tariffs on Canada, Monex Europe analysts say in a note. Any celebrations look somewhat premature, they say. "The Canadian government will likely have to make much more onerous concessions to ensure that the tariff threat is lifted permanently, and this appears far from a done deal to us." This recent drama could resume in a few weeks with risks that next time won't result in another deal for U.S. tariffs to be suspended, they say. USD/CAD trades flat at 1.4434 after hitting a 22-year high of 1.4793 Monday, according to FactSet. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

data.title: Bosnia's indirect tax revenue up 1.3% y/y in Jan
data.description:
SARAJEVO (Bosnia and Herzegovina), February 4 (SeeNews) - Bosnia and Herzegovina's indirect tax revenue increased by 1.25% on the year to 880 million marka ($465.4 million/449.9 million euro) in January, the country's indirect taxation authority said.

After VAT refunds, net revenue from indirect taxes totalled 700 million marka in January, the same as in January last year, the indirect taxation authority said in a statement on Monday.

The net revenue was distributed between the state-level government, the governments of Bosnia's two constituent entities - the Federation and the Serb Republic, and Brcko district.

The bulk of the income was distributed to Bosnia’s entities and Brcko district. The Federation received 369 million marka, the Serb Republic 207 million marka and Brcko district 21 million marka.

(1 euro = 1.956 marka)

data.title: Vodafone's German Business Decline Offset Any Progress — Market Talk
data.description: Vodafone is struggling to remain relevant, AJ Bell's Russ Mould writes in a note. "While there are some reasons for encouragement, the market has tuned these out and is focused on the growing problems in its German operation," Mould says. The London-listed telecom company's U.K. segment showed some growth, ahead of the now-approved merger with Three. However, the group needs to demonstrate it can achieve sustainable growth to reassure investors, Mould says. Shares fall 6.3% to 65.62 pence. (najat.kantouar@wsj.com)

data.title: CIB Marine Bancshares, Inc. Announces Common Stock Repurchase Plan
data.description:
BROOKFIELD, Wis., Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — The Board of Directors of CIB Marine Bancshares, Inc. (the “Company” or “CIB Marine”) (OTCQX: CIBH), the parent company of CIBM Bank, has authorized a 2025 share repurchase program for up to $1 million worth of the Company’s outstanding common stock. This marks the Company’s first common stock repurchase program since completing the repurchase of all Company-issued preferred stock in 2024.

Repurchases are expected to commence in the first quarter of 2025. Common stock may be repurchased in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions. Common share repurchases will be made at the Company’s discretion, with the timing and amount determined by a number of factors, including, the availability of common shares, general market conditions, trading prices, economic conditions, regulatory requirements, and the Company’s financial performance. All stock purchases will be made in accordance with applicable legal requirements. The repurchase program does not obligate the Company to purchase a specific amount of common stock within any particular time frame, and there is no guarantee that any shares will be repurchased upon criteria established by the Company. The Board of Directors will evaluate repurchase conditions at least quarterly to determine the terms and conditions for repurchase activity.

“Having just completed our very successful preferred stock repurchase plan in October, this common stock repurchase program will build off of the momentum of 2024 as we continue to expand meaningful opportunities for shareholder value,” stated Brian Chaffin, President and CEO. “We recognize the important opportunity that current market conditions afford for stock repurchase activity, and the benefits it provides to our shareholders.”

CIB Marine Bancshares, Inc. is the holding company for CIBM Bank, which operates nine banking offices and has mortgage loan officers and/or offices in nine states. More information on the Company is available at www.cibmarine.com, including recent shareholder letters, links to regulatory financial reports, and audited financial statements.

FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS

CIB Marine has made statements in this release that may constitute “forward-looking statements” within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. CIB Marine intends these forward-looking statements to be subject to the safe harbor created thereby and is including this statement to avail itself of the safe harbor. Forward-looking statements are identified generally by statements containing words and phrases such as “may,” “project,” “are confident,” “should be,” “intend,” “predict,” “believe,” “plan,” “expect,” “estimate,” “anticipate” and similar expressions. These forward-looking statements reflect CIB Marine’s current views with respect to future events and financial performance that are subject to many uncertainties and factors relating to CIB Marine’s operations and the business environment, which could change at any time.

There are inherent difficulties in predicting factors that may affect the accuracy of forward-looking statements.

Stockholders should note that many factors, some of which are discussed elsewhere in this release and in the documents that are incorporated by reference, could affect the future financial results of CIB Marine and could cause those results to differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements contained or incorporated by reference in this document. These factors, many of which are beyond CIB Marine’s control, include but are not limited to:

  • operating, legal, execution, credit, market, security (including cyber), and regulatory risks;
  • economic, political, and competitive forces affecting CIB Marine’s banking business;
  • the impact on net interest income and securities values from changes in monetary policy and general economic and political conditions; and
  • the risk that CIB Marine’s analyses of these risks and forces could be incorrect and/or that the strategies developed to address them could be unsuccessful.

These factors should be considered in evaluating the forward-looking statements, and undue reliance should not be placed on such statements. Forward-looking statements speak only as of the date they are made. CIB Marine undertakes no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events, or otherwise. Forward-looking statements are subject to significant risks and uncertainties and CIB Marine’s actual results may differ materially from the results discussed in forward-looking statements.

FOR INFORMATION CONTACT:

J. Brian Chaffin, President & CEO

(217) 355-0900

brian.chaffin@cibmbank.com

data.title: The observation status for Simris Group AB is removed
data.description:
Nasdaq Stockholm ABFirst North Growth Market - Equities

The observation status for Simris Group AB is removed

On October 24, 2024, the shares in Simris Group AB (the “Company”) were givenobservation status with reference to material adverse uncertainty in respect ofthe issuer's financial position.

On December 23, 2024, the Company disclosed a press release with informationthat the Company's board of directors had resolved on a financing package tosecure the working capital in the Company. As part of the finance package, theCompany's board of directors entered into loan agreements which were subject toapproval by the general meeting.

On December 23, 2024, the Company disclosed a notice to an extraordinarygeneral meeting to approve the board of directors' proposal of theaforementioned loan agreements.

On January 20, 2025, the Company disclosed the bulletin from the extraordinarygeneral meeting, which had resolved to approve the board of directors'proposal.

With reference to the above, Nasdaq Stockholm AB decides that the observationstatus for the shares in Simris Group AB (SIMRIS B, ISIN code SE0008091664,order book ID 121365) shall be removed.

For further information about this exchange notice please contact Enforcement &Investigations, telephone +46 8 405 70 50.

Nasdaq Stockholm ABhttps://view.news.eu.nasdaq.com/view?id=bf9a81d888289a877208d4f71da4e9ef9&lang=en&src=omxlink

data.title: CBOE Volatility Index Steady, US Dollar Slips Early Tuesday After China Announces Retaliatory Tariffs
Copper Edges Higher
data.description:
Copper futures rose to over $4.3 per pound in February, a two-week high, supported by traction in the world’s largest manufacturing sectors while markets assessed the impact of trade restrictions between China and the US. US factory activity underwent its first expansion in over two years during January, according to data compiled by the ISM, to support the outlook for base metal demand.

In the meantime, a similar survey by Caixin pointed to an expansion in Chinese factory activity, easing earlier concerns from a contractionary NBS PMI, which faces noise due to volatile stocking/destocking as firms geared for trade barriers with the US and Chinese New Year festivities.

Still, treatment charges in Chinese copper smelters continued to reflect uncertain purchasing levels in the near future.

Beijing signaled a batch of fiscal stimulus to be passed this year, aligned with the traction in credit demand from monetary stimulus, which raised hopes of stronger demand for factory goods.

data.title: Palantir's shares surge on strong forecasts; MS upgrades to 'equal-weight'
data.description:
**Shares of Palantir Technologies jump nearly 19% to $99.5 premarket

**Palantir forecast Q1 and FY revenue above estimates on robust demand for its software and data analytics services

** Morgan Stanley says Palantir is performing well in the early stages of the AI cycle given a strong tech platform and elite engineering talent

** Raises rating to 'equal-weight' from 'underweight'

** Three of 22 brokerages rate the stock "buy" or higher, 14 "hold" and five "sell" or lower; their median PT is $80- LSEG

** PLTR's stock rose ~340.5% in 2024

data.title: Indian Indices Gain on Tuesday as US Delays Tariffs on Canada, Mexico
data.description:
Indian shares climbed on Tuesday, mirroring gains in Asian markets after US President Donald Trump postponed planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico, easing fears of a broader trade war.

The temporary suspension lifted investor sentiment, though tariffs on China remain set to take effect soon.

Meanwhile, focus is shifting to the Reserve Bank of India's Monetary Policy Committee meeting scheduled for Feb. 5 to Feb. 7, with expectations that the central bank could begin its rate-cutting cycle by lowering benchmark rates by 25 basis points.

The BSE Sensex gained 1,397.07 points, or 1.8%, to close at 78,583.81, while the NSE Nifty 50 rose 378.20 points, or 1.6%, to close at 23,739.25.

Larsen & Toubro led the top gainers with a 4.8% rise, followed by Adani Ports and IndusInd Bank .

Among laggards, Zomato , Nestle India , and Maruti Suzuki stood at the top.

In corporate news, Ujjivan Small Finance Bank has submitted a formal application to the Reserve Bank of India for a universal banking license, according to a Tuesday filing.

Meanwhile, HT Media said its board has approved an investment of up to 110 million Indian rupees in its wholly owned subsidiary, Mosaic Media Ventures. The investment aims to support Mosaic Media's business of gathering and distributing news, analysis, and research.

data.title: Nvidia Stock Rises. What Tariff Threats Mean for the AI Chip Maker. — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Adam Clark

Nvidia was gaining early on Tuesday. The chip maker looks set to gain from the wider market relief around last-minute deals that averted the U.S. putting tariffs on goods imported from Mexico and Canada.

Nvidia shares were up 0.8% at $117.60 in premarket trading. The stock fell 2.8% on Monday.

The U.S. gets less than 10% of its imported chips from Canada, Mexico or China, according to analysts at Bernstein Research. However, Taiwan's Foxconn — also known as Hon Hai Precision Industry — has previously said it is building the world's largest manufacturing site for servers to house Nvidia's GB200 Superchips in Mexico. The GB200 is one of Nvidia's Blackwell generation of processors.

President Donald Trump has also threatened to place tariffs on semiconductors coming from Taiwan. The agreements reached with Mexico and Canada could lessen fears over the imposition of similar levies.

Meanwhile, Wall Street will be looking for commitments to investment in AI infrastructure from Google-parent Alphabet when it reports quarterly results after the market closes. Its executives are likely to face questions over the ramifications of Chinese firm DeepSeek's low-cost AI models.

Among other chip makers, Advanced Micro Devices was rising 1.1% and Broadcom was gaining 0.3% in premarket trading.

Write to Adam Clark at adam.clark@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Stocks, dollar stumble as China quickly hits back at US tariffs
data.description:
Key points:
  • US tariffs on China take effect, Beijing quickly imposes own
  • Mexico, Canada tariffs paused after border promises
  • Markets on edge although Monday's big moves unwound

U.S. stock futures and the dollar fell on Tuesday, while Hong Kong shares slipped from two-month highs, as the U.S. and China went tit-for-tat on tariffs and raised the spectre of a broader, damaging trade conflict.

"(The) trade war story remains alive and well and this has a lot further to play out," said Shane Oliver, chief economist at AMP in Sydney, as prices skidded around on news headlines.

S&P 500 futures , which had bounced in relief that Mexico and Canada cut last-minute deals to delay a U.S. tariff hit, swung to a 0.2% loss, while the dollar index erased earlier gains to trade 0.1% lower at 108.86 .

European stocks slipped 0.1% in morning trading after falling 0.87% on Monday. Germany's DAX index was flat and Britain's FTSE 100 CURRENCYCOM:UK100 0.3% lower.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng scaled 2025 highs on hopes that China would also negotiate its way out of tariffs with U.S. President Donald Trump, but later pared its gains slightly to trade about 2.8% higher, buoyed by hopes that Beijing will ramp up stimulus spending to counter U.S. moves.

An additional 10% U.S. tariff on Chinese exports took effect at 0501 GMT, and minutes later Beijing announced it was investigating Google and imposing tariffs on imports of U.S. oil, coal, gas, cars and farm equipment from Feb. 10.

"I'd say there's disappointment that the U.S. tariffs will be implemented following the last-minute reprieve of both Mexico and Canada," said Ben Bennett, Asia-Pacific investment strategist at Legal & General Investment Management in Hong Kong.

"At first look, the Chinese action doesn’t appear overly aggressive, and investors will remain hopeful that both sides will reach an agreement before long and remove the barriers."

The dollar surged against the offshore yuan on Monday but was last down 0.16% on Tuesday. The more liquid Australian dollar , often seen as a proxy for the yuan, was last down 0.3% to $0.6209.

Mainland Chinese markets remained shut for the Lunar New Year break, with investors focusing on where China fixes the currency trading band on Wednesday morning for clues as to whether it will seek to weaken the yuan to limit the impact of tariffs.

Trump's press secretary said he will speak with Chinese President Xi Jinping in the next few days, but unlike the North Americans, it is less clear where they will find common ground.

"It's a totally different story because it (China) is an economic rival as well as political," said Naka Matsuzawa, chief macro strategist at Nomura in Tokyo.

"Unless China makes huge concession economically, I really don't think Trump will stop this tariff."

UNCERTAINTY UNLEASHED

Trump's shifting trade policies have made for a wild start to a week that is also dotted with major company earnings.

The Canadian dollar swung in its biggest one-day range since the onset of the pandemic on Monday, while the S&P 500 fell 1.9% before finishing the session 0.76% lower.

Investor discomfort had safe-haven gold trading just below Monday's record highs at $2,817 an ounce. Bonds fell slightly after ticking higher on Monday, with benchmark 10-year Treasury yields up 3 bps to 4.579% .

The euro was steady at $1.0341 while the dollar rose 0.3% to 155.28 yen .

"For the Federal Reserve, the weekend's developments will likely reinforce their inclination to sit on the sidelines and to remain below the radar as much as possible," noted J.P. Morgan's chief U.S. economist, Michael Feroli.

UBS Group trounced forecasts with fourth-quarter profits and announced a buyback. BNP Paribas (BNPP.SA) also beat earnings forecasts but lowered this year's profit target.

Google reports after U.S. markets close on Tuesday and scrutiny will be on its massive AI spending after the apparently much cheaper Chinese model DeepSeek shocked markets last week.

Brent crude oil prices, which initially rose on Monday, were down around 1% after touching their lowest in a month at $74.81 a barrel.
